ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.

What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I witnessed a significant improvement in my academic writing capacity. I also have built fairly comprehensive knowledge framework of censorship in the United States.

When I signed up for ENGL 114, I was told that my writing would change completely  I'd never go back to writing the way I did before. While I agree with this sentiment somewhat, I don't think my writing changed in the way I thought it would. I don't believe this class improved my grammar/writing structure, but it did alter the way I support my arguments. I think Professor Robinson was very skilled in getting students to break free from the so-called "template" writing that was learned in high school. He really helped me focus on a single argument and support it fully without veering from the topic at hand, which was extremely helpful.
How to analyze different pieces of literature related to censorship, how to structure different types of academic essays

I learned a lot about what is important in writing. We focused less on the small things like font/margins and more on the core of the essay like the thesis and the support. There was a huge emphasis on having a corrective and contestable claim. We wrote papers that discussed ideas from readings. Some papers were structured more as research papers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The strength of this course is that Professor Robinson gives you timely and helpful feedback to your paper, which means that you are able to improve your first draft. He also pays lots of attention to individual students, via commenting and meeting.

Strengths: Professor Robinson provides extremely clear feedback on each essay you submit for this class. I think the practice of submitting a draft before getting a final grade helped to strengthen my writing and the final quality of the paper because it allowed us to make corrections without receiving any penalty. I also liked the size of the class, as it really forced people to chat about the topics in an environment that wasn't too intimidating.

Weaknesses: Though minor, I felt that sometimes Prof. Robinson talked a little too much, and it was a little difficult to add your insight into the conversation without feeling like you were interrupting him. I think we actually had some classes where each student only spoke for about 10 seconds. While this was a little comforting/sheltering if you had nothing important to say/skipped a reading or two, it would have been more beneficial to be forced to talk and critique each other. I think the only improvement I would make to this course is the addition of some time for students to converse with each other instead of conversations with just Prof. That said, I'm not sure what this class would be like in person, but this is what I felt over Zoom.

The main strength of this course is definitely Professor Robinson. While all of the 114 sections teach similar writing techniques, Professor Robinson makes the class environment laid back and welcoming for all, which I really enjoyed. He is also always willing to meet outside of class to discuss essay topics and feedback on drafts, which I also found especially useful. Overall, definitely recommend this section--no real weaknesses I can think of!

I appreciated how this was a small course that allowed me to be engaged with the professor and my classmates. 

There was a little more reading than I anticipated but it was not horrible.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Robinson is very understanding of the stress and anxiety involved in remote learning. He supports students academically and personally.

I think Zoom had positives and negatives this semester. I honestly believe the most effective virtual learning practice that was in effect for this course only occurred during the penultimate class, when Prof. Robinson put us into breakout rooms. I think individual meetings with the professor on our writing would be more beneficial, in addition to the comments left on papers.
The professor was very accommodating about deadlines and meeting times.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to other students, particularly those who are interested in censorship and law. This course gives me a solid foundation in the legal precedents and practices in censorship.

Yes. As a pre-med student, it's often necessary to take ENGL 114, and honestly, compared to what my friends mentioned about their sections, Prof. Robinson's class was far more laid back, and Prof. Robinson was more understanding and compassionate towards his students. I think this is a low stress class focused on discussion of weekly readings and a couple essays   not much more than that. The structure of this class was a nice pairing with some heavier courses that may be less focused on individual students.

Yes, if they can take it with Professor Robinson! I think 114 in general really depends on the professor teaching the section, but taking it with Professor Robinson was definitely enjoyable. It's a relatively low-stress way of learning about important writing techniques and getting a WR credit. The main topic (censorship) is also especially relevant in today's political climate, which to me was an added bonus.
Yes! If you need a writing credit or want a good foundational English/writing class, this is a great one!
